awd_titl_txt: RCN: INCyTE: Investigating Nutrient Cycling in Terrestrial Ecosystems: Integrating Observations, Experiments, and Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Very few ecosystems are fertile enough to support high rates of plant productivity.  This is not due to lack of carbon dioxide, whose concentration in the atmosphere has been on the increase.  Rather, it is due to the growth-limiting effects caused by the lack of other available nutrients in soil,  especially nitrogen and phosphorous.  Nevertheless, computer ecosystem models used to estimate the response of plants to increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide predict that this environmental change will result in more rapid and abundant plant growth globally. Such models fail to incorporate the effects of other limiting nutrients on plant growth. This project will bring together experimental scientists and computer modelers to explore the effects of nutrients on plant growth, determine whether nutrient supplies are adequate to promote the growth predicted by models, and decide how to best represent the effects of nutrients in global computer models. Research coordination via this network is important for establishing how the carbon cycle is likely to change in response to global environmental change, with important implications for soil fertility and agriculture.  The project will train multiple early career scientists, foster a number of diverse international collaborations, and engage with broad audiences using multiple scientific and social media platforms.

The proposed Research Coordination Network (INCyTE) will bring together two communities that historically have not interacted closely: biogeochemical experimentalists and earth system modelers. The overarching goals of INCyTE are to enhance our understanding of nutrient cycling feedbacks on the global carbon (C) cycle in general, and to integrate different investigators, data, and experimental and conceptual frameworks to improve representation of nutrient interactions and constraints on the global terrestrial C cycle in Earth System Models (ESMs). While nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus and others) have the potential to mediate plant growth responses to elevated carbon dioxide (and interact with a host of other global changes), only a handful of current global simulation models even attempt to represent those interactions and feedbacks. This project will: 1) Identify gaps in understanding/representation of modeled C-nutrients feedbacks and processes; 2) Coordinate a number of small-scale, coummunity-based, high-throughput experiments to address particular hypotheses and identify candidate processes for further attention; 3) Use network syntheses and community-based experimental data to enhance model representation of nutrient cycling; and 4) Employ new ESM inter-comparisons. Scientifically, the proposed work has the potential to vastly increase the ability to predict if and how nutrients may constrain the global terrestrial C cycle and enhance understanding of how nutrient-C cycle feedbacks may influence environmental change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Human activities like fossil fuel combustion and land conversion and land use change are driving substantial increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentrations. Such changes have been linked to climate change, ocean acidification, and changes to the global carbon (C) cycle, among others. Our understanding of the future effects of ongoing increases in atmospheric CO2 are largely based on simulation models, but those models only include a subset of the most important biogeochemical processes that are critical for ecosystem function. The overarching goals of INCyTE (Investigating Nutrient Cycling in Terrestrial Ecosystems) were to enhance our understanding of nutrient cycling feedbacks on the global carbon (C) cycle in general, and more specifically, to integrate different investigators, data, and experimental and conceptual frameworks to inform computer models that make predictions about the global terrestrial C cycle. Our work was guided by four primary objectives, and some of the most important outcomes of our research are described below.

Our first objective was to Identify the most significant gaps in our understanding of nutrient cycling, nutrient limitation, and their spatially explicit effects on the global C cycle and develop a strategy to address those shortcomings. Through a series of meetings and online workshops and seminars, the INCyTE Network of more than 125 scientists identified three areas of critical research: 1) the effects of changing nutrient concentrations (known as stoichiometry) on the C cycle; 2) the patterns and controls on nitrogen (N) fixation – a process that brings most N into natural ecosystems; and 3, how phosphorus availability – another often limiting nutrient – influences the C cycle. Most of the rest of our activities focused on these three important gaps. Among other things, we learned that changes ratios of C:nutrients resulting from increases in CO2 are likely to slow the pace at which plants are currently growing, due to increasing limitations posed by other nutrients. If so, we would expect that C storage on land may plateau or even decline, and this could increase the pace of future climate change.

Our second objective was to evaluate current simulation models, how they work, how they reconcile with ecological understanding gained from on the ground measurements and prioritize a strategy for improvement of models and for validating model output. To that end, members of our group compared models to see how differently they performed. We also designed an experiment (objective 4) to sample and analyze plant tissues from around the world. Those data are now being used to test assumptions commonly used in models and to improve how the models represent important ecosystem processes. For example, many models do not represent how changes in plant C:nutrient ratios may affect plant growth. Our work shows the importance of considering this important interaction, and efforts are underway to include stoichiometry in new versions of the models.

Our third objective was to consider how changing element ratios are or may change how land ecosystems function in the future. We found that changing stoichiometry may have strong negative effects on plant production, C storage, and even the water cycle. We also explored the importance of an underappreciated set of organisms to N inputs to ecosystems. We found that most current models do not include this missing set of nutrient inputs, and our work will be important for improving them in the future.

The final objective of our work was to use the information we learned during the project to help inform the next generation of models used to predict future C cycling and climate. When we started this work, few (if any) of the global models used to inform the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change included phosphorus cycling. However, at least two of the models developed by INCyTE members are now able to simulate P dynamics and how they may affect global C cycling. Other aspects of this part of the work are still ongoing, but we are confident that the combined set of knowledge gained during our project will lead to improved predictions about how terrestrial ecosystems are likely to function in the future.

Results from this work have been disseminated to both scientific and general audiences, and funds from this grant directly supported the training of early career researchers at the US Geological Survey, Cornell University, Princeton University, Cal Tech, and the University of Montana.
